+batlizard37
While courts aren't required to include members of a defendant's race to 
create "a jury of peers," attorneys cannot exclude a juror based on race 
during jury selection. In Batson v. Kentucky, James Batson, an African 
American man, was on trial for burglary and receipt of stolen goods. The 
prosecutor in the case used peremptory challenges to exclude all four 
African American members of the jury pool, effectively creating an 
all-white jury.
After being convicted of the crimes, Batson appealed the decision to the 
U.S. Supreme Court, arguing that the removal of the black jurors violated 
his rights under the Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments. The Court ruled in 
Batson's favor.
- See more at: 
http://criminal.findlaw.com/criminal-procedure/what-is-a-jury-of-peers.html#sthash.k83dOM8l.dpuf

+concious2 If you want to blame the "Fry Mumia" movement for 
cherry-picking, I suggest you do exactly as you suggest: "Read the entire 
case not just what you want to believe". The "Myth of the Running Man" that 
Professor Fernandez mentions (2:12) is a recycled lie that is a mere 
patchwork crock that takes bits and pieces of court testimony and 
eyewitness reports on the night when Wesley Cook (a.k.a. Mumia Abu Jamal) 
brutally murdered Officer Daniel Faulkner and assembles those bits into one 
desperate narrative. The four witnesses who supposedly identified the 
Running Man as the shooter were: 1) Dessie Hightower, 2) Deborah Kordansky, 
3) Veronica Jones and 4) Robert Chobert. First, Hightower reported that he 
was going to his car in the parking lot of Club Whispers, heard gunshots, 
looked up, looked down and looked up again and saw two men running from the 
scene. Never mind that Hightower didn't see the actual murder. What the 
professor likely won't say is that Hightower described one of those men as 
a 6"0 dreadlocked person wearing a red and black sweater. Is it just a 
coincidence that Wesley Cook is 6"0, had/has dreadlocks and wore a red and 
black jacket on the night of the murder? Second, Kordansky was in her room 
at the St. James Hotel and reported that she heard gun shots, saw police 
sirens then looked out her window. ". Never mind that she never saw the 
murder. Never mind that she didn't testify at the 1982 trial because she 
was convinced that her testimony wouldn't advance either the prosecution or 
defense. All she said to police was that she "...saw someone run". She 
didn't even say which direction the Running Man was running. Maybe she saw 
Hightower and his friend, who, according to Hightower, ran toward the scene 
after hearing gunshots. Maybe she saw prosecution witness Michael Scanlan, 
who saw the murder then ran from the scene toward Broad Street to look for 
police to help Officer Faulkner - who was sadly dead by then. Third, 
Veronica Jones was a prostitute who stood on a street corner two whole 
blocks away from the scene. Jones admitted that she was high on drugs at 
the time and merely said that she only only saw two men jogging across 
Locust St, which essentially means crossing the street. Meanwhile, Jones 
testified in court that she didn't see anything. Fourth, Robert Chobert was 
a PROSECUTION witness who told police that he saw the assailant run from 
the scene. Chobert was the only witness who actually saw the murder. He 
also told police that the assailant fell shortly after beginning running 
away. He also identified the fallen man as none other than Wesley Cook, who 
was - go figure - seated on the sidewalk when police arrived. In fact, 
Chobert fingered Wesley Cook in court and said: "I saw you, buddy! I never 
took my eyes off of you!" There was also a fifth witness who contributed to 
the "Myth of the Running Man", William Singletary. However, his fantasy 
tale was suppressed by defense attorneys and Wesley Cook himself because 
his BS was so outlandish. All that seemingly matters to proponents of 
Wesley Cook is that the witnesses used the word "run". It's the equivalent 
of Googling the term "run" from the witness reports and court testimony and 
piecing the results together to concoct the bogus "Myth of the Running 
Man". Pretty lame, huh? So, as you said "adding untruths is wrong". 
However, you're blaming the wrong people of doing so. Practice what you 
preach to stonegroovejason, and read the entire case. Maybe YOU will 
uncover the truth.

2. On the night that Officer Faulkner was shot there were four persons at 
the crime scene. But the prosecutor, Joe McGill, and the trial judge, 
Albert Sabo, concealed the presence at the crime scene of that fourth 
person at trial. In fact, the presence of that fourth person, the passenger 
in the Volkswagen which Officer Faulkner had stopped, was acknowledged by 
prosecutor Joe McGill in another trial that was happening concurrently, 
surrounding the same crime scene. This key, exculpatory evidence -- that 
there was another person at the crime scene who was the passenger -- was 
hidden from the defense and the jury. Why?


My Rebuttal------------------------------------------------------------
There was nothing to conceal. The four witnesses she is referring to are 
Debra Kordansky, Desie Hightower, Veronica, and Robert Chobert. Of those 
four witnesses only Robert Chobert said he saw the actual shooting. The 
rest admitted that they didn't see anything until AFTER the shooting was 
finished. Thus they have NO WAY of identifying any shooted much less 
claiming the shooter ran and managed to get away.

1. Debra Kordansky

Ms. Kordansky stated that she was in her bedroom watching TV when the 
shooting occurred. In her original statement to police she said that she 
“didn’t go to her window until drawn there by the flashing lights of the 
police cars that had already arrived on the scene”. She also stated while 
looking out her window, she saw “someone run.” While being questioned by 
Leonard Weinglass at the 1995 PCRA hearing, Kordansky specifically stated 
that this person “was not the shooter” and that “they ran after police had 
already arrived”. (N.T. 8/3/95, 248-249)

2. Desie Hightower

Mr. Hightower stated that he was down the street, behind a building in a 
parking lot, getting into a car when the shooting occurred. When asked by 
police at the scene if he could identify Jamal as the shooter Hightower 
told them, “I couldn’t say, because I didn’t see the officer actually 
shot.” (N.T. 6/28/82, 28.131)

3. Veronica Jones

Ms. Jones has always stated that she was over 2 blocks away, around a 
corner and behind a building, when Officer Faulkner was shot. In 1996 she 
testified that she “waited for a few minutes” before looking around the 
corner to see what happened and that she then saw two men approach Officer 
Faulkner’s body. She further stated, “I was not there, I did not see him 
[the shooter].” (N.T. 10/1/96, 24)

She neglects to mention that there were four other witnesses in addition to 
Robert Chobert who actually saw the shooting. Each of them gave separate 
reports to separate officers that all said the shooter ran to the scene, 
killed Officer, ran a few feet and then collapsed on the corner which is 
exactly where Mumia was found with his gun by his side with all of the 
shots having been fired.

7. The prosecution pegged the murder of Officer Daniel Faulkner on Mumia
